content.question: In an experiment, an external torque is applied to the edge of a disk of radius <math alttext="0.5 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> such that the edge of the disk speeds up as it continues to rotate. The tangential speed as a function of time is shown for the edge of the disk. The rotational inertia of the disk is <math alttext="0.125 kilogram meter squared " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.125</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext><mo>â‹…</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>. Can a student use the graph and the known information to calculate the net torque exerted on the edge of the disk?

choices.label: Yes, because the slope of the graph multiplied by the rotational inertia is equal to the net torque exerted on the edge of the disk.
Yes, because the change in tangential speed per unit of time can be multiplied by the rotational inertia divided by the radius of the disk.
No, because the net force exerted on the edge of the disk must first be determined before the net torque can be calculated.
No, because the change in tangential speed of the edge of the disk per unit of time cannot be used to determine the angular acceleration of the disk.

content.answer: Yes, because the change in tangential speed per unit of time can be multiplied by the rotational inertia divided by the radius of the disk.
